author: Jane Harper
title: Volatility ‘won’t scare off shoppers’
text:
TILLS will continue to ring for now, retail industry leaders say, as they watch to see how the share market volatility filters through to consumers.
As the market on Tuesday recovered most of its losses from a massive sell-off on Monday, retailers hoped any knock to confidence would be short-lived.
“People are still going to shop,” Australian Retailers Association executive director Russell Zimmerman said. “People still need groceries and other staples.
“They might think a little bit more about discretionary goods, but we are going into a new season which will help.
“I’m not expecting people to put away their wallets.”
Mr Zimmerman said while many consumers would be aware of the activity on the markets, most would not feel an immediate short-term impact.
“There are a lot of shoppers out there who don’t have shares,” he said.
“For most people they are a long-term investment or part of their super fund.
“While they may feel a bit of a downturn, I don’t think it’s going to impact retail.”
But Monday’s share market plunge came just as consumer sentiment was starting to pull back.
While confidence levels hit seven-week highs earlier this month, figures slipped 0.2 per cent last week, according to Roy Morgan research. Levels last week were 0.4 per cent lower than a year ago.
“The longer that the sell-off on global markets continues, the more impact it will have,” CommSec chief economist Craig James said.
 Volatility ‘won’t scare off shoppers’
